title: 106_hr2678
content: SECTION 1. REQUIREMENTS OF PROMOTERS OF SKILL CONTESTS OR SWEEPSTAKES MAILINGS. Section 1 of Chapter 30 of title 39, United States Code, requires promoters of skill contests or sweepstakes mailings to comply with specific regulations. Additionally, a new section 3016 is added, defining terms like 'promoter', 'removal request', and 'skill contest'. The regulations in Chapter 30 of title 39, United States Code, require compliance for skill contests and sweepstakes mailings. Nonmailable matter includes contests requiring a purchase to enter and sweepstakes that are games of chance with no consideration needed. Nonmailable matter includes skill contests or sweepstakes that do not comply with regulations. Promoters must provide a notice with each mailing that includes contact information for a notification system to prohibit future mailings. Promoters must establish a notification system for individuals to exclude their names from mailing lists for skill contests or sweepstakes. Individuals can elect to be excluded by submitting a request. Promoters must establish a notification system for individuals to exclude their names from mailing lists for skill contests or sweepstakes. Individuals can elect to be excluded by submitting a removal request, which must be honored within 35 days. The election to be excluded remains in effect unless the individual notifies the promoter in writing to change it. Promoters are not liable for excluding names from mailing lists for skill contests or sweepstakes if a removal request is received and believed to be from the individual or an authorized person. Commercial use of lists derived from this information is prohibited. The commercial use of lists derived from individuals who exercise an election under subsection (d) is prohibited. Violators may face a civil penalty of up to $2,000,000 per violation. Promoters who recklessly mail nonmailable matter may be liable for a penalty of $10,000 per violation for each mailing to an individual. The Postal Service can assess civil penalties for mailing nonmailable matter or failing to comply with requirements. The commercial use of lists from individuals opting out is prohibited, with violators facing penalties of up to $2,000,000 per violation. Promoters mailing nonmailable matter recklessly may be fined $10,000 per violation. The amendments made by this section regarding nonmailable skill contests or sweepstakes matter shall take effect 1 year after the enactment of this Act.
